thread.title: San Jose State begins key three-game home stretch
thread.title_full: San Jose State begins key three-game home stretch

author:
Jeff Faraudo

jfaraudo@bayareanewsgroup.com
title: San Jose State begins key three-game home stretch
text:
San Jose State begins key three-game home stretch By Jeff Faraudo Posted: 10/12/2015 02:24:59 PM PDT Updated: 10/12/2015 02:25:02 PM PDT SAN JOSE -- San Jose State begins a crucial run of three straight home games Saturday against San Diego State, feeling good about itself after snapping a seven-game road losing streak. 
"When you fight through a tough game like that, it builds character, it shows resiliency," said coach Ron Caragher of the Spartans' 33-27 overtime win at UNLV that allowed them to square their record at 3-3 and improve to 2-1 in the Mountain West Conference. "Those are great things that add value over the course of the season." 
The boost comes just in time to face the Aztecs (3-3, 2-0), defending co-champions and current leaders of the West Division. If the Spartans want to challenge for the West title, this is a game they need to win. 
"As you continue winning, the bar gets raised," Caragher said. "I use the analogy we're climbing the mountain. With that win, we moved our base camp a little higher up the mountain. The higher you get, the steeper the climb is." 
It's a far different scenario than a year ago, when SJSU had dropped five in a row entering its season finale at San Diego State and lost 38-7. Caragher called the game "a distant memory," but said it served to motivate his team throughout the offseason. 
"It's a painful experience when you're on the wrong end of those lopsided scores," he said. "It was a game we definitely had to look in the mirror after that (to see) where we're at and what we're doing. Advertisement 
"I think our team responded well in the offseason. We know we're playing a good team. What a great opportunity we have." 
-- The Spartans have clarity at quarterback after junior Kenny Potter confirmed his status as the starter with a strong outing at UNLV. Potter, back in the lineup after missing the two previous games with an ankle injury, was intercepted on SJSU's first series, then cleaned up his game. 
"Kenny really came up big," Caragher said. "We all saw he was rusty in the first quarter. But he really answered the call after that first quarter. I'm encouraged by how Kenny has played." 
Potter was 30 for 48 for 329 yards with two touchdowns and the interception. He also ran three times for 33 yards and a TD. Senior Joe Gray, who had played well in the two previous games, is the backup. 
-- SJSU senior running back Tyler Ervin remains the nation's No. 2 rusher with 874 yards, trailing only LSU's Leonard Fournette, who has 1,022 yards. Ervin is fourth in yards per game at 145.7 and tied for third with 11 rushing touchdowns. 
If he gains 126 yards against the Aztecs, Erwin would become just the fourth Mountain West player to reach 1,000 in his seventh game of the season. 
-- Linebacker Christian Tago left the locker room Saturday wearing a protective boot on his right foot, but Caragher said it was purely precautionary and he will be cleared to practice Tuesday. 
-- Fans can check out the five Super Bowl trophies won by the 49ers and three by the Raiders on Saturday at Spartan Stadium's east field as part of The Tour 50: Champions of the Bay exhibit. The event is free and the trophies will be on display from 3:30 to 7:30 p.m.
